fields.label_text:
LONGCASE CLOCK
ENGLISH; about 1700
Oak carcase with walnut veneer and seaweed marquetry.

The dial signed Hen Godfrey London.

Bequeathed by Miss Amy E. Jones.

fields.label:
LONGCASE CLOCK
ENGLISH; about 1700
Oak carcase with walnut veneer and seaweed marquetry.

The dial signed Hen Godfrey London.

Bequeathed by Miss Amy E. Jones. [pre October 2000]
fields.credit: Bequeathed by Miss Amy E. Tomes
fields.history_note:
Bequest of Miss Amy E Tomes of Welbeck House, Wigmore Street, London W1, 12 November 1940 (killed by enemy action - a bomb)

Notes from R.P. 1532/40, 6667/35, 1403/40

31 October 1940 letter, Executors of Tomes to the Museum
listed among the objects bequeathed:
"Marquetry clock made by Henry Godfrey (1685)" with pencil notations in margin "seaweed, good".

12 November 1940, Transit Room notes
Long case marquetry clock, with winder & key, two weights & pendulum (split, parts loose, marquetry faulty).

Notes from R.P. 1532/40, 1403

3/10/40 Letter Tomes executors to the V & A
includes a list of items bequeathed giving the Museum full discretion to use in any way they see fit.  Among the items of furniture listed is "marquetry clock made by Henry Godfrey 1685".  Handwritten notations on the letter put parentheses around the date and notes "Dr R Z" "….seaweed, good" next to the clock entry.

12/11/40 Bequest Form
lists among the 39 articles bequeathed
"W.50 
1 Long case marquetry clock (with winder & key, two weights & pendulum)"

12/11/40 Handwritten list of furniture
includes notes regarding the condition of the clock "(split, parts loose, marquetry faulty)"

RP 1403 40 - 25 Sept 1940 Registry Memo
Reports the death of Miss Amy E Tomes "recently killed in consequence of enemy action (by a bomb)…"

13/12/40 Further file memo
refers to this as "a generous bequest in some respects in the same firmament as the Browett Gift, though a number of the objects are…inferior" and suggests a special display of the articles.

The will itself, dated 22 February 1938
lists among the furniture bequeathed to the V & A
" (ii) My Marquetry clock made by Henry Godfrey 1685"

R.P.420 - Earlier file notes from 1936 
refer to Clifford Smith's inspection of the furniture at Miss Tomes flat.  This "Furniture…was collected by a great-uncle…about forty years ago and was until recently in her father's house, Mannington Hall, Norfolk".  Many sets of chairs are discussed and a follow-up letter from the Director to Tomes suggests several items that would be particularly suitable for inclusion in any bequest including the "marquetry clock in the drawing-room".  Tomes agrees to bequeath the items listed by Smith.

7/6/37 Inspection report (R.P. 37/2553?) by (CM?)
notes that "The clock in the drawing-room looks a very fine one, with seaweed marquetry"
